The enhancement of O⨪2 generation by low concentrations of ONOO− or NOR-1 was associated with activation of the ERK MAPKs and was blocked by their inhibition. Thus, low physiological levels of NO⋅present following PMN activation are converted to ONOO−, which enhances O⨪2 generation through activation of the ERK MAPK pathway, whereas higher levels of NO⋅ or ONOO−feed back and inhibit O⨪2 generation. This biphasic concentration-dependent regulation of the PMN oxidant burst by NO⋅-derived ONOO− may be of critical importance in regulating the process of inflammation. polymorphonuclear leukocytes superoxide nitric oxide peroxynitrite mitogen-activated protein kinase extracellular signal-regulated kinase MAPK/ERK kinase 5-(diethoxyphosphoryl)-5-methyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,4,6-trimethyl-3,3-disulfonatophenyl)porphyrinato iron(III) The influx and activation of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs)1 are of critical importance in the process of tissue inflammation (1Shandelya S.M.L. Kuppusamy P. Weisfeldt M.L. Zweier J.L. Circulation. 1993; 87: 536-546Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). PMNs are chemotaxed and then activated at sites of tissue injury with the generation of oxygen free radicals and the release of proteolytic enzymes and other toxic products (2Rowe G.T. Eaton L.R. Hess M.L. J. Mol. Cell. Cardiol. 1984; 16: 1075-1079Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). Activated human PMNs generate superoxide (O⨪2) during their respiratory burst via the NADPH oxidase complex (3Babior B.M. Peters W.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 2321-2323Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). It has been reported that high levels of nitric oxide (NO⋅) can directly inhibit O⨪2 generation from stimulated PMNs (4Clancy R.M. Leszczynska-Piziak J. Abramson S.B. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 1116-1121Crossref PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar, 5Fujii H. Ichimori K. Hoshiai K. Nakazawa H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32773-32778Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). NO⋅ can also react with O⨪2derived from PMNs or other sources to form the potent oxidant peroxynitrite (ONOO−). However, questions remain regarding the effects of low physiological levels of NO⋅ and how these or ONOO− modulate the NADPH oxidase function of and O⨪2 generation from PMNs. NO⋅ can inhibit PMN-endothelial cell adhesion in the microcirculation and thus potentially exert anti-inflammatory effects (6Kubes P. Suzuki M. Granger D.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 4651-4655Crossref PubMed Scopus (2811) Google Scholar). In contrast, it has been observed that increased NO⋅generation leads to cytotoxicity following sepsis, ischemia, and reperfusion (7Schulz R. Wambolt R. Cardiovasc. Res. 1995; 30: 432-439PubMed Google Scholar) or anoxia and reoxygenation (8Matheis G. Sherman M.P. Buckberg G.D. Haybron D.M. Young H.H. Ignarro L.J. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 262: H616-H620PubMed Google Scholar). It has been demonstrated that ONOO− is formed by the reaction of O⨪2 and NO⋅ in post-ischemic tissues and following the process of inflammation (9Wang P. Zweier J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 29223-29230Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar). It has also been shown that O⨪2plays a key role in NO⋅-induced toxicity, and previously proposed mechanisms for both O⨪2- and NO⋅-mediated tissue injury now include a role for their combined reaction product, ONOO− (10Tarpey M.M. Beckman J.S. Ischiropoulos H. Gore J.Z. Brock T.A. FEBS Lett. 1995; 364: 314-318Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). The reaction between O⨪2 and NO⋅ is extremely fast, almost diffusion-limited in rate (2 × 109m−1s−1) (11Huie R.E. Padmaja S. Free Radic. Res. Commun. 1993; 18: 195-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (2015) Google Scholar). ONOO− is a potent oxidant that can attack a wide variety of biological molecules and is produced in diverse inflammatory and pathological processes, including post-ischemic injury (7Schulz R. Wambolt R. Cardiovasc. Res. 1995; 30: 432-439PubMed Google Scholar, 9Wang P. Zweier J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 29223-29230Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar), septic shock (12Szabo C. Salzman A.L. Ischiropoulos H. FEBS Lett. 1995; 372: 229-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar), and atherosclerosis (13Beckman J.S. Ye Y.Z. Anderson P.G. Chen J. Accavitti M.A. Tarpey M.M. White C.R. Biol. Chem. Hoppe-Seyler. 1994; 375: 81-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1070) Google Scholar). ONOO− can directly oxidize sulfhydryl groups (14Radi R. Beckman J.S. Bush K.M. Freeman B.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4244-4250Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and also reacts by both 1- and 2-electron oxidation reactions with a variety of biological target molecules (15Beckman J.S. Chen J. Ischiropoulos H. Crow J.P. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 233: 229-240Crossref PubMed Scopus (965) Google Scholar). Notably, ONOO−-mediated nitration of tyrosine residues on a variety of proteins is associated with loss of enzyme or receptor function (16Beckman J.S. Koppenol W.H. Am. J. Physiol. 1996; 271: C1424-C1437Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, it has been reported that mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) are important in the regulation of leukocyte function and the PMN oxidative burst (17Babior B.M. Curr. Opin. Hematol. 1995; 2: 55-60Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar, 18Downey G.P. Butler J.R. Tapper H. Fialkow L. Saltiel A.R. Rubin B.B. Grinstein S. J. Immunol. 1998; 160: 434-443PubMed Google Scholar, 19McLeish K.R. Knall C. Ward R.A. Gerwins P. Coxon P.Y. Klein J.B. Johnson G.L. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1998; 64: 537-545Crossref PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). These kinases are also modulated by various oxidants; and based on these interactions, it has been suggested that O⨪2 or secondary oxidants are important mediators of cellular signaling. Three groups of MAPK superfamilies have been identified in mammalian cells: the extracellular signal-regulated kinases 1 and 2 (ERK-1 and ERK-2), the c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase (also termed stress-activated protein kinase), and p38MAPK (20Derijard B. Raingeaud J. Barrett T. Wu I.H. Han J. Ulevitch R.J. Davis R.J. Science. 1995; 267: 682-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (1409) Google Scholar). Two isoforms of ERK, ERK-1 (p44MAPK) and ERK-2 (p42MAPK), are expressed in PMNs (21Torres M. Hall F.L. O'Neill K. J. Immunol. 1993; 150: 1563-1577PubMed Google Scholar), and they transduce signals elicited via several receptors that either have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity or are associated with non-receptor tyrosine kinases (22Blenis J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 5889-5892Crossref PubMed Scopus (1157) Google Scholar). MAPK kinases (MEKs) are dual-specificity kinases that phosphorylate MAPKs such as ERK (23Zheng C.F. Guan K.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23933-23939Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). MEKs have been detected in PMNs and have been shown to be critical for ERK activation (24Grinstein S. Butler J.R. Furuya W. L'Allemain G. Downey G.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 19313-19320Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 25Downey G.P. Butler J.R. Brumell J. Borregaard N. Kjeldsen L. Sue-A-Quan A.K. Grinstein S. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 21005-21011Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). It has been reported that ERK may participate in activation of the PMN oxidative burst since one of the cytosolic components of the NADPH oxidase (p47phox ) contains two serine residues within a sequence that is recognized by proline-directed kinases (26El Benna J. Faust L.P. Babior B.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 23431-23436Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) such as ERK and since phosphorylation of p47phox is involved in NADPH oxidase activation (27Inanami O. Johnson J.L. McAdara J.K. Benna J.E. Faust L.R. Newburger P.E. Babior B.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 9539-9543Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar). Furthermore, recent studies have reported that MEK and ERK contribute to activation of the oxidative burst of human PMNs (18Downey G.P. Butler J.R. Tapper H. Fialkow L. Saltiel A.R. Rubin B.B. Grinstein S. J. Immunol. 1998; 160: 434-443PubMed Google Scholar, 19McLeish K.R. Knall C. Ward R.A. Gerwins P. Coxon P.Y. Klein J.B. Johnson G.L. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1998; 64: 537-545Crossref PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). However, it is unknown if there is a direct interaction between NO⋅ or ONOO− and these pathways of activation. Therefore, in this study, we determined the concentration-dependent effects of NO⋅ and ONOO− on activation of and O⨪2 generation from PMNs. O⨪2 generation was directly measured via EPR spin trapping with the use of the O⨪2-specific trap DEPMPO, whereas NO⋅ concentrations were monitored by NO⋅ electrode. In addition to characterizing the effects of high pharmacological levels of NO⋅, the effects of low physiological levels were studied. At these low levels, it was observed that ONOO−, formed from the reaction of NO⋅ with PMN-derived O⨪2, triggered MAPK-mediated increases in O⨪2 generation from the NADPH oxidase, whereas with high levels of NO⋅ or ONOO−, inhibition of the oxidase was seen. PIPES, EGTA, EDTA, d-glucose, NaF, Na4P2O7, Na3VO4, 2-mercaptoethanol, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA), Nonidet P-40, bovine serum albumin, dithiothreitol, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, Tris-HCl, and urate were from Sigma. NOR-1 ((±)-(E)-methyl-2-((E)-hydroxyimino)-5-nitro-6-methoxy-3-hexenamide) was from BIOMOL Research Labs Inc. (Plymouth Meeting, PA). The ONOO− decomposition catalyst 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,4,6-trimethyl-3,3-disulfonatophenyl)porphyrinato iron(III) (FeTMPS) was obtained from Monsanto Corp. (St. Louis, MO). The following materials were from the indicated sources: Percoll and peroxidase-linked sheep anti-mouse Ig antibody, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech; Tris and Tween 20, Bio-Rad; leupeptin, Roche Molecular Biochemicals; anti-phosphotyrosine monoclonal antibody 4G10, from Upstate Biotechnology, Inc. (Lake Placid, NY); phospho- and non-phospho-MAPK (ERK-2) control proteins, mouse anti-phospho ERK-1 and ERK-2 (p44MAPK and p42MAPK) antibodies, and biotinylated molecular weight markers, New England Biolabs Inc. (Beverly, MA); and PD98059 and crystallized human serum albumin, Calbiochem. NO⋅ was scrubbed of higher nitrogen oxides by passage through a trap with solid NaOH pellets and a second trap with 1 m de-aerated (bubbled with argon for 30 min) NaOH solution. NO⋅ gas-equilibrated solution was prepared using 500 ml of phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) that was de-aerated by bubbling with argon for 30 min and then bubbled with scrubbed NO⋅ for 30 min (28Liu X. Miller M.J.S. Joshi M.S. Thomas D.D. Lancaster Jr., J.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 2175-2179Crossref PubMed Scopus (530) Google Scholar, 29Liu X. Miller M.J. Joshi M.S. Sadowska-Krowicka H. Clark D.A. Lancaster Jr., J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 18709-18713Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (424) Google Scholar). To further verify the precise NO⋅ concentration derived from NO⋅gas-equilibrated solutions, electrochemical measurement of NO⋅concentrations were carried out at 25 °C using a Model 832 detector with a Faraday cage and NO⋅ electrode (CH Instruments, Inc., Cordova, IN). The ONOO− was synthesized from acidified nitrite and hydrogen peroxide according to Beckman et al. (15Beckman J.S. Chen J. Ischiropoulos H. Crow J.P. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 233: 229-240Crossref PubMed Scopus (965) Google Scholar). Alternatively, similarly prepared ONOO− was obtained from Alexis Corp. (San Diego, CA). The concentration of ONOO− was checked at the time of synthesis and again just prior to each experiment by absorbance measurements at 302 nm (extinction coefficient of 1670m−1cm−1), and only ONOO− that was >95% of the original concentration was used. To assure that pH did not change significantly upon addition of alkaline ONOO−to the reaction mixture, we also monitored the pH and limited the amount of alkaline ONOO− stock used. Human PMNs were isolated from freshly sampled venous blood of volunteers by Percoll density gradient centrifugation (30Schleimer R.P. Rutledge B.K. J. Immunol. 1986; 136: 649-654PubMed Google Scholar), which yielded PMNs with a purity of >95%. Each 10 ml of whole blood was mixed with 0.8 ml of 0.1m EDTA and 25 ml of saline. The diluted blood was layered over 9 ml of Percoll at a specific density of 1.080 g/ml. After centrifugation at 400 × g for 20 min at 20 °C, the plasma, mononuclear cell, and Percoll layers were removed. Erythrocytes were lysed by addition of 18 ml of ice-cold water for 30 s, followed by 2 ml of 10× PIPES buffer (25 mm PIPES, 110 mm NaCl, and 5 mm KCl, titrated to pH 7.4 with NaOH). Cells were pelleted at 4 °C, the supernatant was decanted, and the procedure was repeated. After the second hypotonic lysis, cells were washed twice with PAG buffer (PIPES buffer containing 0.003% human serum albumin and 0.1% glucose). Afterward, PMNs were counted by light microscopy on a hemocytometer. The final pellet was then suspended in PAG-CM buffer (PAG buffer with 1 mmCaCl2 and 1 mm MgCl2). All EPR measurements were performed using a Bruker ER 300 EPR spectrometer operating at X-band with a TM110 cavity. The microwave frequency was measured with a Model 575 microwave counter (EIP Microwave, Inc., San Jose, CA). To measure O⨪2 generation from PMA-stimulated PMNs, EPR spin-trapping studies were performed using DEPMPO (Oxis, Portland, OR) at 10 mm (31Roubaud V. Sankarapandi S. Kuppusamy P. Tordo P. Zweier J.L. Anal. Biochem. 1997; 247: 404-411Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). The instrument settings used in the spin-trapping experiments were as follows: modulation amplitude, 0.32 G; time constant, 0.16 s; scan time, 60 s; modulation frequency, 100 kHz; microwave power, 20 milliwatts; and microwave frequency, 9.76 GHz. The samples were placed in a quartz EPR flat cell, and spectra were recorded. The component signals in the spectra were identified and quantified as reported (31Roubaud V. Sankarapandi S. Kuppusamy P. Tordo P. Zweier J.L. Anal. Biochem. 1997; 247: 404-411Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). The double integrals of DEPMPO-OOH experimental spectra were compared with those of a 1 μm TEMPO standard measured under identical settings to estimate the concentration of the O⨪2 adduct. Dissolved NO⋅ gas solutions were used to determine the effects of NO⋅ pre-exposure on subsequent O⨪2 generation from PMA-stimulated PMNs (4 × 106 cells/ml). Electrode measurements confirmed that after 10 min, no detectable NO⋅ remained, ensuring that NO⋅would not significantly scavenge O⨪2 generated from the stimulated PMNs. Therefore, dissolved NO⋅ gas (0–100 μm) was added to the PMNs in PAG-CM buffer (pH 7.4) at 37 °C; and after 10 min, PMA (1 ng/ml) was added, and O⨪2generation was measured by EPR. For experiments with ONOO−pre-exposure, ONOO− (0–100 μm) was added with a gas-tight syringe to PMNs in PAG-CM buffer (pH 7.4) at 37 °C; and after 1 min, the PMNs were stimulated by addition of PMA (1 ng/ml), and O⨪2 generation was measured by EPR spin trapping. As previously reported, ONOO− rapidly decays at pH 7.4 with a half-life of <1 s (15Beckman J.S. Chen J. Ischiropoulos H. Crow J.P. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 233: 229-240Crossref PubMed Scopus (965) Google Scholar); and after 1 min, no detectable ONOO− remains. To achieve sustained release of NO⋅continuing during the PMN oxidative burst so as to trigger intrinsic ONOO− generation, the NO⋅ donor NOR-1 (0–100 μm) was used, and PMNs were immediately stimulated with PMA after addition of NOR-1. PMNs in PAG-CM buffer were subjected to the same experimental conditions described above; reactions were stopped by addition of ice-cold PAG buffer; and the PMNs were rapidly pelleted. Cell pellets were immediately lysed in lysis buffer (50 mmTris HCl (pH 7.5), 5 mm EDTA, 10 mm EGTA, 5 mm dithiothreitol, 1% Nonidet P-40, 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 mg/ml leupeptin, 100 μg/ml aprotinin, 10 mm benzamidine, 50 mm NaF, 5 mm Na4P2O7, and 1 mm Na3VO4). Extracts from an equal number of PMNs (106 cells/lane) were diluted with an equal volume of 2× loading buffer (0.125 m Tris-HCl (pH 6.8), 4% SDS, 0.005% bromphenol blue, 20% glycerol, and 5% 2-mercaptoethanol) and subjected to 4–20% Tris/glycine gradient gel electrophoresis (Novex, San Diego, CA). After electrophoresis, gels were then transferred to pure nitrocellulose membranes (Schleicher & Schüll) with TransBlot (Novex). After transfer, membranes were immersed in TBST (50 mm Tris (pH 7.5), 0.15 mNaCl, and 0.05% Tween 20) containing 5% nonfat dried skim milk overnight to block nonspecific binding. Membranes were then washed three times (5 min each) with TBST. Immunoreactive proteins were detected using anti-phospho-ERK-1 and -ERK-2 antibodies (0.5 μg/ml) in TBST containing 1% skim milk. After 4 h of incubation, membranes were washed with TBST and then incubated with peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse Ig antibody for 1 h. After five 10-min washes, membrane-bound anti-mouse Ig antibody was visualized with ECL Western blotting detection reagents (Pierce), and Hyper ECL luminescence detection film (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). The enhanced chemiluminescence film images were converted to digital format with a URL digital camera, and the images were analyzed with National Institutes of Health Image (32Miura K. Schroeder J.T. Hubbard W.C. MacGlashan Jr., D.W. J. Immunol. 1999; 162: 4198-4206PubMed Google Scholar). Although the comparisons were made on the basis of equal numbers of cells, the protein contents of these samples were also found to be equal. All the experiments were performed in triplicate and repeated a minimum of three times. Results are expressed as means ± S.E. Statistical analysis was performed using Student's t test or one-way analysis of variance. Ap value <0.05 was considered to be statistically significant. The dose-dependent effects of NO⋅ and ONOO− pretreatment on O⨪2generation from PMA-stimulated PMNs were measured by EPR spin trapping with DEPMPO. Preliminary experiments were performed to determine the dose-dependent effects of PMA and to identify a concentration that would provide significant but less than half-maximal activation. As reported previously (31Roubaud V. Sankarapandi S. Kuppusamy P. Tordo P. Zweier J.L. Anal. Biochem. 1997; 247: 404-411Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar), after addition of PMA (1–100 ng/ml) to PMNs, we observed primarily a characteristic DEPMPO-OOH adduct spectrum with hyperfine splitting giving rise to 12 resolved peaks (Fig. 1 A, spectra b–d). The O⨪2 adduct DEPMPO-OOH comprised 92% of the total intensity, and the DEPMPO-OH adduct 8%. The DEPMPO-OOH signals increased as a function of the PMA concentration (Fig. 1). PMA is known to be a strong activator of protein kinase C. As shown in Fig. 1 B, at concentrations >10 ng/ml, PMA resulted in near-maximal levels of O⨪2 generation, suggesting full activation of the NADPH oxidase complex. Since maximal PMA activation could mask other stimulatory effects, in experiments evaluating the effects of NO⋅ and ONOO− on O⨪2 generation from PMNs, PMA concentrations of 1 ng/ml were used so as to provide about one-third of the maximal activation. We examined the effects of NO⋅ pre-exposure on subsequent PMN function. PMNs were exposed to given initial concentrations of NO⋅ prepared using NO⋅ gas, and the concentration of NO⋅ in solution was monitored by NO⋅ electrode. After 10 min, when the NO⋅ concentration decayed to near zero, PMA was added to trigger O⨪2 generation from the PMNs. After addition of PMA (1 ng/ml), a large signal of DEPMPO-OOH and a small signal of DEPMPO-OH was observed (Fig. 2 A, spectrum a). We observed that low concentrations of NO⋅ (1 μm) had no effects on the magnitude or kinetics of DEPMPO-OOH formation (Fig. 2, A, spectrum b; and B), whereas with high concentrations of NO⋅ (100 μm), the DEPMPO-OOH signal was significantly decreased (Fig. 2 A,spectrum c; and B and C). The effects of pre-exposure of PMNs to ONOO− on subsequent O⨪2generation were also studied. It was observed that low ONOO− concentrations (1 μm) markedly increased O⨪2 generation following PMA stimulation, with higher levels of DEPMPO-OOH spin adduct seen (Fig. 3, A, spectra a and b; and B). In contrast, pretreatment with high levels of ONOO− (100 μm) markedly inhibited subsequent PMA-stimulated O⨪2 generation (Fig. 3, A, spectra b andc; and B). In further experiments, the dose-dependent effects of NO⋅ and ONOO−on subsequent O⨪2 generation from PMA-stimulated PMNs were determined. It was observed that ONOO− concentrations up to 10 μm increased O⨪2 generation, whereas ONOO− concentrations over 50 μm decreased O⨪2 generation (Fig. 3 C). With NO⋅, however, low concentrations did not alter O⨪2 generation, and only inhibition was seen at high levels (Fig. 2 C). These data suggest that ONOO− can exert a concentration-dependent biphasic modulation of O⨪2generation from the PMN NADPH oxidase.Figure 3Effect of ONOO − on O⨪2 generation from PMNs. A, EPR spin-trapping measurement of O⨪2generation from PMA-stimulated PMNs in PAG-CM buffer (pH 7.4). ONOO− (1 or 100 μm) was preincubated with PMNs (4 × 106 cells/ml) for 1 min before PMA (1 ng/ml) stimulation in PAG-CM buffer (pH 7.4), and then O⨪2generation was measured by EPR spin trapping with DEPMPO (10 mm). Spectrum a, in the absence of ONOO−, a prominent spectrum of DEPMPO-OOH with only a small signal of DEPMPO-OH was seen with relative intensities of 92 and 8%, respectively. Spectrum b, with addition of ONOO− (1 μm), the DEPMPO-OOH signal was increased >2-fold. Spectrum c, with addition of ONOO− (100 μm), the DEPMPO-OOH signal was decreased ∼3-fold, and the DEPMPO-OH adduct was seen with relative intensities of 47 and 53%, respectively. B, time course of O⨪2 generation from ONOO− (1 or 100 μm)-pretreated PMNs. C, dose-dependent effects of ONOO− (1–100 μm) on O⨪2 generation. *, significance ofp < 0.01 for the increase from the corresponding value of PMA (1 ng/ml)-stimulated PMNs; †, significance of p< 0.01 for the decrease from the corresponding value of PMA (1 ng/ml)-stimulated PMNs.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) In activated PMNs, ONOO− is likely to be formed from the reaction of extrinsic NO⋅ and PMN-derived O⨪2. Furthermore, since ONOO− is a reactive short-lived species, its intrinsic generation near or within PMNs could be of particular importance. To generate sustained release of NO⋅ continuing during the PMN oxidative burst so as to trigger intrinsic ONOO− generation, the NO⋅ donor NOR-1 (0–100 μm) was used, and PMNs were immediately stimulated with PMA after addition of NOR-1. When NOR-1 (1 μm) was added to PMNs, the DEPMPO-OOH signal was increased by >2-fold from levels in the absence of the NO⋅donor (Fig. 4, A,spectrum b; and B), in a manner similar to that seen with extrinsic ONOO−. With addition of NOR-1 (100 μm), the DEPMPO-OOH signal was decreased by >5-fold (Fig. 4, A, spectrum c; andB). These data indicate that low concentrations of NO⋅ present at the time of O⨪2 generation enhance this latter process, whereas high concentrations of NO⋅ either inhibit or scavenge the O⨪2 generation. The dose-dependent effects of NOR-1 on O⨪2generation from PMA-stimulated PMNs were characterized, and it was observed that NOR-1 concentrations as low as 0.5 μm and as high as 5 μm increased O⨪2 generation 2–3-fold from PMA-stimulated PMNs, whereas NOR-1 concentrations over 10 μm decreased O⨪2 generation in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 4 C). Similarly, 100 nm to 1 μm NO⋅ added at the time of PMA stimulation using NO⋅ gas-equilibrated solution increased the subsequent level of O⨪2 generation. To characterize the time course of NO⋅ release from NOR-1 and the concentration of NO⋅ in the presence of non-activated and PMA-activated PMNs, NO⋅ electrode measurements were performed. In non-activated PMNs, NO⋅ solution concentrations initially increased over the first 5 min after NOR-1 addition and then achieved a plateau, which was followed by a gradual decrease over the next 10 min (Fig. 5). A similar time course was seen with 1, 10, or 100 μm NOR-1 (Fig. 5, A–C). In activated PMNs, the observed NO⋅ concentrations were markedly decreased, with complete scavenging seen with 1 μm NOR-1, a prominent decrease with 10 μm NOR-1, and only a partial decrease with 100 μm NOR-1. The total absence of detectable NO⋅ with 1 μm NOR-1 suggests that all of the NO⋅ release was scavenged by PMN-derived O⨪2generation. This was confirmed by experiments with superoxide dismutase, where it was observed that superoxide dismutase (200 units/ml) prevented the decrease in NO⋅ concentrations seen in activated PMNs. With 1 μm NOR-1, peak NO⋅concentrations of ∼30 nm were measured, indicating that these low physiological levels of NO⋅ could be sufficient to trigger the process of ONOO−-mediated stimulation of O⨪2 generation. To confirm that the ONOO− formation was the basis by which low doses of NOR-1 stimulated PMN O⨪2 generation, we investigated the effects of the ONOO− scavenger urate and the ONOO− decomposition catalyst FeTMPS on this process. It was observed that the NOR-1 (1 μm)-mediated O⨪2 enhancement was almost totally blocked by urate (10 μm) and totally blocked by FeTMPS (10 nm) (Fig. 6 A). In contrast, the decrease in DEPMPO-OOH adduct formation seen with 100 μmNOR-1 was only slightly altered by urate and FeTMPS. Neither urate nor FeTMPS could prevent inhibition of O⨪2 generation mediated by pretreatment with NO⋅ gas (100 μm) (Fig. 6 B). Leukocyte Biol. 1998; 64: 537-545Crossref PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). To understand the mechanism by which extrinsic or intrinsic PMN-generated ONOO− enhances PMN O⨪2 generation, we examined the relationship between ERK activation and O⨪2generation. In preliminary experiments, we verified that PMA (1–100 ng/ml) induced the phosphorylation of ERK-1 and ERK-2 in a PMA concentration-dependent manner. Acetylation of polyamines by spermidine/spermineN 1-acetyltransferase (SSAT) has been implicated in their degradation and/or export out of the cell. The relationship of SSAT to polyamine pool dynamics and cell growth is not yet clearly understood. MCF-7 human breast carcinoma cells were transfected with tetracycline-regulated (Tet-off) SSAT human cDNA or murine gene. Doxycycline removal for >2 days caused a ∼20-fold increase in SSAT RNA and a ∼10-fold increase in enzyme activity. After 4 days, intracellular putrescine and spermidine pools were markedly lowered, and cell growth was inhibited. Growth inhibition could not be prevented with exogenous polyamines due to a previously unrecognized ability of SSAT to rapidly acetylate influxing polyamines and thereby prevent restoration of the endogenous pools. Instead, cells accumulated high levels of N 1 -acetylspermidine,N 1 -acetylspermine, andN 1,N 12 -diacetylspermine, a metabolite not previously reported in mammalian cells. Doxycycline deprivation before treatment withN 1,N 11-diethylnorspermine markedly increased analog induction of SSAT mRNA and activity and enhanced growth sensitivity to the analog by ∼100-fold. Overall, the findings demonstrate that conditional overexpression of SSAT lowers polyamine pools, inhibits cell growth, and markedly enhances growth sensitivity to certain analogs. The enzyme also plays a remarkably efficient role in maintaining polyamine pool homeostasis during challenges with exogenous polyamines. Acetylation of polyamines by spermidine/spermineN 1-acetyltransferase (SSAT) has been implicated in their degradation and/or export out of the cell. The relationship of SSAT to polyamine pool dynamics and cell growth is not yet clearly understood. MCF-7 human breast carcinoma cells were transfected with tetracycline-regulated (Tet-off) SSAT human cDNA or murine gene. Doxycycline removal for >2 days caused a ∼20-fold increase in SSAT RNA and a ∼10-fold increase in enzyme activity. After 4 days, intracellular putrescine and spermidine pools were markedly lowered, and cell growth was inhibited. Growth inhibition could not be prevented with exogenous polyamines due to a previously unrecognized ability of SSAT to rapidly acetylate influxing polyamines and thereby prevent restoration of the endogenous pools. Instead, cells accumulated high levels of N 1 -acetylspermidine,N 1 -acetylspermine, andN 1,N 12 -diacetylspermine, a metabolite not previously reported in mammalian cells. Doxycycline deprivation before treatment withN 1,N 11-diethylnorspermine markedly increased analog induction of SSAT mRNA and activity and enhanced growth sensitivity to the analog by ∼100-fold. Overall, the findings demonstrate that conditional overexpression of SSAT lowers polyamine pools, inhibits cell growth, and markedly enhances growth sensitivity to certain analogs. The enzyme also plays a remarkably efficient role in maintaining polyamine pool homeostasis during challenges with exogenous polyamines. ornithine decarboxylase putrescine spermidine spermidine/spermine N 1-acetyltransferase spermine tetracycline N 1-acetylspermidine, AcSpm,N 1-acetylspermine N 1,N 12-diacetylspermine Chinese hamster ovary cells N 1,N 11-diethylnorspermine α-difluoromethylornithine doxycycline high performance liquid chromatography kilobase pair(s) Intracellular polyamine pools appear to be sensitively regulated by various homeostatic responses that typically include effectors of polyamine biosynthesis, catabolism, and transport. Best known among these are the key enzymes involved in polyamine biosynthesis, ornithine decarboxylase (ODC)1andS-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase. Increases in ODC are often associated with initiation of normal cell growth and with sustained neoplastic cell growth. Overexpression of ODC activity is a well recognized feature of many cancers, and in at least one tumor type, this increase in activity has been attributed to a point mutation leading to stabilization of the typically labile enzyme protein (1Tamara A. Nishiguchi S. Kuroki T. Koh N. Kobayashi K. Yano Y. Otani S. Cancer Res. 1995; 55: 3500-3503PubMed Google Scholar). Such findings form the rationale for certain cancer therapeutic and prevention strategies targeting polyamine metabolism. These efforts rely on inhibitors to block biosynthetic enzyme activity (2Mamont P.S. Duchesne M-C. Grove J. Bey P. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1978; 81: 58-66Google Scholar, 3Kramer D.K. Khomutov R.M. Bukin Y.V. Khomutov A.R. Porter C.W. Biochem. J. 1989; 259: 325-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 4Danzin C. Marchal P. Casara P. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1990; 40: 1499-1503Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 5Regenass U. Mett H. Stanek J. Muller M. Kramer D. Porter C.W. Cancer Res. 1994; 54: 3210-3217PubMed Google Scholar) or, alternatively, on polyamine analogs to down-regulate enzyme activities (6Porter C.W. Regenass U. Bergeron R.J. Dowling R.H. Fölsch U.R. Löser C. Falk Symposium on Polyamines in the Gastrointestinal Tract. Kluwer Academic Publishers Group, Dordrecht, Netherlands1992: 301-322Google Scholar, 7Bergeron R.J. Feng Y. Weimar W.R. McManis J.S. Dimova H. Porter C. Raisler B. Phanstiel O. J. Med. Chem. 1997; 40: 1475-1494Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). In the course of studying the cellular effects of bis-ethylated spermidine and spermine analogs, investigators (8Erwin B.G. Pegg A.E. Biochem. J. 1986; 238: 581-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 9Libby P.R. Bergeron R.J. Porter C.W. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1989; 38: 1435-1442Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 10Casero Jr., R.A. Celano P. Ervin S.J. Porter C.W. Bergeron R.J. Libby P. Cancer Res. 1989; 49: 3829-3833PubMed Google Scholar) found that in addition to down-regulating ODC and S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase, certain analogs potently up-regulate the polyamine catabolic enzyme, spermidine/spermineN 1-acetyltransferase (SSAT). The enzyme acetylates higher polyamines that are then either excreted out of the cell or acted upon by a flavin-adenine-dependent polyamine oxidase, leading to the back-conversion of spermine (Spm) to spermidine (Spd) and Spd to putrescine (Put) (11Seiler N. Can. J. Physiol. Pharmacol. 1987; 65: 2024-2035Crossref PubMed Scopus (223) Google Scholar, 12Casero R.A. Pegg A.E. FASEB J. 1993; 7: 653-661Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar). In the absence of specific SSAT inhibitors, the metabolic significance of changes in enzyme activity has not yet been clearly discerned. In fact, the role of this enzyme in modulating intracellular polyamine pools is largely inferred from its enzymatic function. Much of what is known regarding the cellular consequences of SSAT is based on studies with polyamine analogs such asN 1,N 11-diethylnorspermine (DENSPM), which potently induce the enzyme (9Libby P.R. Bergeron R.J. Porter C.W. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1989; 38: 1435-1442Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 10Casero Jr., R.A. Celano P. Ervin S.J. Porter C.W. Bergeron R.J. Libby P. Cancer Res. 1989; 49: 3829-3833PubMed Google Scholar, 13Pegg A.E. Wechter R. Pakala R. Bergeron R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 11744-11749Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 14Porter C.W. Ganis B. Libby P.R. Bergeron R.J. Cancer Res. 1991; 51: 3715-3720PubMed Google Scholar). Cause and effect relationships have been difficult to establish with such analogs since, as noted above, they have other effects on polyamine metabolism and are known to exert a somewhat paradoxical inhibition of the SSAT enzyme (15Libby P.R. Ganis B. Bergeron R.J. Porter C.W. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 284: 238-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Our earlier studies examined SSAT function in fetal fibroblasts from transgenic animals that overexpress SSAT (16Pietilä M. Alhonen L. Halmekytö M. Kanter P. Jänne J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18746-18751Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar, 17Alhonen L. Karppinen A. Uusi-Oukari M. Vujcic S. Korhonen P. Halmekytö M. Kramer D.L. Hines R. Jänne J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 1964-1969Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). A 10-fold increase in enzyme activity was found to correlate with lowered Spd and Spm pools and increased Put and acetylated polyamine pools. More recently, McCloskey et al. (18McCloskey D.E. Coleman C.S. Pegg A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6175-6182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) stably overexpressed SSAT in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells and observed similar polyamine pool perturbations. Since in both instances cell growth was not affected, we reasoned that metabolic adaptations that took place following transfection may have masked the effects of SSAT overexpression on polyamine pool dynamics and cell growth. In this present study, we investigated the polyamine and cellular consequences of conditional SSAT expression. In particular, we derived cells transfected with either the human SSAT cDNA or the murine SSAT gene under the control of a tetracycline-regulatable (Tet-off) promoter (19Gossen M. Bujard H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 5547-5551Crossref PubMed Scopus (4268) Google Scholar). The results demonstrate a previously unappreciated ability of SSAT to (a) regulate intracellular polyamine pools against a huge extracellular gradient, (b) diacetylate Spm, (c) negatively affect cell growth, and (d) markedly enhance growth inhibition by polyamine analogs. The Spm analogueN 1,N 11-diethylnorspermine (DENSPM (20Bergeron R.J. McManis J.S. Liu C.Z. Feng Y. Weimar W.R. Luchetta G.R. Wu Q. Ortiz-Ocasio J. Kramer D.L Porter C.W. J. Med. Chem. 1994; 37: 3464-3476Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar)) was supplied by Warner Lambert Parke-Davis (Ann Arbor, MI).N 1,N 12-Diacetylspermine was very kindly provided by Dr. Nikolaus Seiler (Strasbourg, France). A MCF-7 cell line stably transfected with a Tet-off transfection system was purchased fromCLONTECH Laboratories Inc. (Palo Alto, CA). The cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Life Technologies, Inc.) supplemented with 2 mm glutamine, 10% fetal bovine serum, penicillin at 100 units/ml, streptomycin at 100 units/ml, and the antibiotic G418 (Life Technologies) at 100 μg/ml at 37 °C in the presence of 5% CO2. Cells were harvested by trypsinization and counted electronically (Coulter Model ZM, Coulter Electronics, Hialeah, FL). 1 mm aminoguanidine was routinely included in the media as an inhibitor copper-dependent bovine serum amino oxidase to prevent oxidation of extracellular polyamines to toxic products. Latino R. Gasparini P. Zalante L. Focus. 1997; 19: 58-59Google Scholar). To facilitate clone selection, cells were co-transfected with a pTK-Hyg vector (CLONTECH Laboratories, Inc.). Transfected clones resistant to 100 μg/ml hygromycin B (CLONTECH Laboratories, Inc.) were selected and tested for SSAT enzyme activity and/or mRNA in the presence or absence of 200 ng/ml doxycycline hydrochloride (Dox, Sigma-Aldrich). In the presence of Dox (+Dox), SSAT transcription is not induced; in the absence of Dox (−Dox), SSAT transcription is induced. A Dox concentration of 200 ng/ml was found to be the minimum antibiotic concentration required to fully and consistently suppress SSAT gene expression during cell culture passage. Clones that expressed the lowest basal levels of SSAT activity or mRNA in +Dox and the highest induced level of SSAT activity or mRNA in −Dox were selected for further study. Clones were maintained continuously under +Dox conditions until experiments were initiated. Intracellular polyamines including acetylated polyamines and polyamine analogs were extracted from cell pellets with 0.6 n perchloric acid, dansylated, and measured by reverse phase HPLC as described previously (24Kabra P.M. Lee H.K. Lubich W.P. Marton L.J. J. Chromatogr. Biomed. Appl. 1986; 380: 19-32Crossref Scopus (238) Google Scholar) with the following modifications. Dansylated samples (50 μl) were injected onto a 250-mm x 3.2-mm internal diameter Econosil C18 column (5-μm particle size, Alltech, Deerfield, IL) with a column temperature of 50 °C and eluted by a two-solvent gradient using a Waters 616 LC system (Waters Corporation, Milford, MA) and a Waters WISP 710B autosampler. Solvent A contained 55% 10 mm ammonium phosphate, 45% acetonitrile at pH 4.4. Solvent B contained 100% acetonitrile. At 0.9 ml/min, the gradient began at 100% solvent A and progressed linearly to 82% solvent B over 30 min with a 15-min hold. Compounds were detected using a McPherson FL-750 BX fluorescence detector (McPherson, Acton, MA) with an excitation wavelength of 360 nm and an emission cut-off filter of 500 nm. The data were collected and analyzed using Millennium 32 chromatography software (version 3.05). Total RNA was extracted with guanidine isothiocyanate and purified by cesium chloride gradient centrifugation. Human SSAT cDNA probe (21Xiao L. Celano P. Mank A.R. Pegg A.E. Casero Jr., R.A. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1991; 179: 407-415Google Scholar) was used in Northern blot analyses. ODC and SSAT enzyme activities were assayed as reported earlier (14Porter C.W. Ganis B. Libby P.R. Bergeron R.J. Cancer Res. 1991; 51: 3715-3720PubMed Google Scholar). Cells transfected with either the human SSAT cDNA (MCF-7/hSc) or the murine SSAT gene (MCF-7/mSg) were selected in hygromycin and grown as clones in the presence of Dox. Of 11 MCF-7/hSc clones (Fig. 2), those most sensitive to Dox regulation were selected according to the differential between SSAT mRNA in the presence of Dox (+Dox, SSAT-uninduced)versus mRNA in the absence of Dox (−Dox, SSAT-induced). Clone H-12, which was ideal in this regard, was lost in passaging. Subsequent attention focused on clone H-10, which displayed a 20–30-fold increase in SSAT mRNA (Figs. 2 and3) after Dox removal for 48 h. The SSAT mRNA from the transfected human cDNA (∼1.5 kb) was clearly distinguishable from the smaller (∼1.3 kb) endogenous transcript, presumably because of differences in polyadenylation, which we have previously shown to be affected by enzyme induction (25Fogel-Petrovic M. Shappell N.W Bergeron R.J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19118-19125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Notice that although the exogenous 1.5-kb transcript levels increased with Dox removal, the endogenous 1.3-kb transcript levels remained the same. One unexpected finding was the appearance of two bands in the region of ∼3.5-kb SSAT RNA that previous studies (25Fogel-Petrovic M. Shappell N.W Bergeron R.J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19118-19125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have shown to be heteronuclear (hnRNA) in origin. Since these could not have originated from the cDNA, we can only speculate that induced SSAT gene expression may in some way interfere with processing of the endogenous heteronuclear RNA, but this remains to be investigated. The same selection strategy, applied to MCF-7 cells transfected with the murine SSAT gene (MCF-7/mSg cells), led to the identification of the M-3 clone (shown in Fig. 8). The M-3 clone showed a ∼3-fold increase in SSAT mRNA after Dox removal for 48 h. As expected for transfected genomic sequences, this SSAT mRNA was apparent as a mature ∼1.3-kb species comparable in size with the endogenous message and as a less abundant preprocessed ∼3.5-kb RNA. The time dependence of Dox-regulated expression of SSAT mRNA and activity was characterized in the newly selected H-10 clone (Fig. 3). After Dox removal, SSAT mRNA increased most rapidly during the first 6 h, after which it reached a plateau that typically ranged between 19- and 34-fold. This induction of mRNA was accompanied by a more modest rise in SSAT activity, which reached a maximum of ∼10-fold range (see Fig. 3 and TableI). The time-dependent metabolic consequences of SSAT overexpression on polyamine metabolism were evaluated in the H-10 clone (Table I). Interestingly, there did not appear to be a compensatory rise in ODC activity as has been seen in systems bearing stably transfected SSAT (16Pietilä M. Alhonen L. Halmekytö M. Kanter P. Jänne J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18746-18751Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar, 17Alhonen L. Karppinen A. Uusi-Oukari M. Vujcic S. Korhonen P. Halmekytö M. Kramer D.L. Hines R. Jänne J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 1964-1969Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 18McCloskey D.E. Coleman C.S. Pegg A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6175-6182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The typical ∼10-fold increase in SSAT activity was seen to have an obvious effect on polyamine pools. After 48-h of Dox, Put pools were lowered by ∼45% relative to zero time, Spd pools were lowered by ∼54%, and Spm was not significantly affected. At 96 h, Spd pools were further decreased to <30% zero control, indicating the progressive effect of SSAT overexpression. Consistent with SSAT enzymatic function, acetylated polyamine pools were profoundly increased. N 1-Acetyl-Spd increased from <5 to 1750 and 2285 pmol/106 cells by 48 and 96 h, respectively. The other enzyme productN 1 -acetyl-Spm, which is rarely seen in cells, increased from <5 pmol/106 cells in +Dox cells to 165 pmol/106 cells in −Dox cells at 96 h. We also noted significant amounts of a novel polyamine peak that was subsequently identified asN 1,N 12 -diacetyl-Spm (see below), which accumulated to 190 pmol/106 cells by 96 h. In contrast to a previous report (18McCloskey D.E. Coleman C.S. Pegg A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6175-6182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) studying CHO cells stably transfected with SSAT, N 8-acetyl-Spd was not detected in these cells. Very similar trends were observed in M-3 cells transfected with murine SSAT genomic sequences (MCF-7/mSg cells, Table I). As with the H-10 cells, Put and Spd pools decreased with the former, falling to 36% of the zero control, and the latter, to 25% of control by 96 h. In previous studies with SSAT transgenic mice (16Pietilä M. Alhonen L. Halmekytö M. Kanter P. Jänne J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18746-18751Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar) and in the embryo fibroblasts derived from them (17Alhonen L. Karppinen A. Uusi-Oukari M. Vujcic S. Korhonen P. Halmekytö M. Kramer D.L. Hines R. Jänne J. Porter C.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 1964-1969Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar), Put pools increased rather than decreased. This may be because ODC activity increased in the stably transfected systems but remained relatively constant during conditional overexpression of SSAT (Table I). Fig. 4 shows that conditional overexpression of SSAT causes a sustained reduction in growth in both H-10 or M-3 cells after Dox removal. M-3 cells were more sensitive than H-10 cells even though Spd pools were similarly depleted in both clones (Table I). In both cases, the growth response appeared to be cytostatic rather than cytotoxic in nature, since cell proliferation continued albeit at a reduced rate. The data in Table I and Fig. 4 indicate that SSAT overexpression and the attendant inhibition of cell growth may be directly related to a reduction in intracellular Spd pools. Because Spd is generally regarded as the polyamine most critically required for cell growth (3Kramer D.K. Khomutov R.M. Bukin Y.V. Khomutov A.R. Porter C.W. Biochem. J. 1989; 259: 325-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), we investigated whether it could prevent growth inhibition. This strategy is typically employed to validate the specificity of polyamine enzyme inhibitors (2Mamont P.S. Duchesne M-C. Grove J. Bey P. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1978; 81: 58-66Google Scholar, 3Kramer D.K. Khomutov R.M. Bukin Y.V. Khomutov A.R. Porter C.W. Biochem. J. 1989; 259: 325-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). For these studies, H-10 cells were continuously exposed (or not exposed) to 10 μm Spd after Dox removal. As shown in Fig. 5, 10 μm Spd failed to prevent growth inhibition associated with SSAT induction. Although this would suggest that Spd depletion is not responsible for growth inhibition, polyamine pool analysis (TableII) revealed that intracellular Spd pools in −Dox cells were not restored by this treatment. Rather,N 1-acetyl-Spd accumulated to enormous levels (5660 pmol/106 cells), whereas Spd pools remained at <50% that seen in +Dox cell levels, apparently because overexpressed SSAT rapidly converts influxing Spd to the acetylated derivative. These findings prompted us to examine whether higher concentrations of Spd might be able to saturate SSAT and allow for restoration of Spd pools and prevention of growth inhibition. Here, we encountered the unexpected finding that external Spd concentrations as high as 500 μm were still unable to restore intracellular Spd pools (Fig. 6) or to prevent growth inhibition (Table III and Fig. 6 legend). Although cells grown +Dox and treated with increasing levels of exogenous Spd clearly accumulated higher than normal Spd levels (up to 150%), cells grown −Dox did not. Intracellular Spd pools remained at subnormal levels, whereas N 1-acetyl-Spd rose to extremely high levels, increasing from <5 to >14,000 pmol/106 cells during treatment with 500 μm Spd. In many epithelial tissues in the body (e.g. kidney distal nephron, colon, airways) the rate of Na+ reabsorption is governed by the activity of the epithelial Na+ channel (ENaC). ENaC activity in turn is regulated by a number of factors including hormones, physiological conditions, and other ion channels. To begin to understand the mechanisms by which ENaC is regulated, we have examined the trafficking and turnover of ENaC subunits in A6 cells, a polarized, hormonally responsive Xenopus kidney cell line. As previously observed by others, the half-life of newly synthesized ENaC subunits was universally short (∼2 h). However, the half-lives of α- and γ-ENaC subunits that reached the apical cell surface were considerably longer (t12 > 24 h), whereas intriguingly, the half-life of cell surface β-ENaC was only approximately 6 h. We then examined the effects of various modulators of sodium transport on cell surface levels of individual ENaC subunits. Up-regulation of ENaC-mediated sodium conductance by overnight treatment with aldosterone or by short term incubation with vasopressin dramatically increased cell surface levels of β-ENaC without affecting α- or γ-ENaC levels. Conversely, treatment with brefeldin A selectively decreased the amount of β-ENaC at the apical membrane. Short term treatment with aldosterone or insulin had no effect on cell surface amounts of any subunits. Subcellular fractionation revealed a selective loss of β-ENaC from early endosomal pools in response to vasopressin. Our data suggest the possibility that trafficking and turnover of individual ENaC subunits at the apical membrane of A6 cells is non-coordinately regulated. The selective trafficking of β-ENaC may provide a mechanism for regulating sodium conductance in response to physiological stimuli. The selective trafficking of β-ENaC may provide a mechanism for regulating sodium conductance in response to physiological stimuli. epithelial sodium channel Xenopus ENaC vasopressin brefeldin A polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis The kidney regulates extracellular fluid volume in the body through modulation of Na+ reabsorption along the nephron. The ultimate regulation of Na+ reabsorption occurs at the apical surface of collecting ducts and is mediated by the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC).1 ENaC is also located at the apical membrane of other epithelial tissues throughout the body, including colon, sweat glands, and airway (1Garty H. Palmer L.G. Physiol. Rev. 1997; 77: 359-396Crossref PubMed Scopus (1043) Google Scholar). Abnormalities of function of this channel, linked to inherited alterations in channel structure, have been shown to be important in several human diseases, including the hypertension seen in patients with Liddle's Syndrome (2Shimkets R.A. Warnock D.G. Bositis C.M. Nelson-Williams C. Hansson J.H. Schambelan M. Gill Jr., J.R. Ulick S. Milora R.V. Findling J.W. et al.Cell. 1994; 79: 407-414Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1205) Google Scholar) and the salt-wasting seen with some variants of psuedohypoaldosteronism (3Chang S.S. Grunder S. Hanukoglu A. Rosler A. Mathew P.M. Hanukoglu I. Schild L. Lu Y. Shimkets R.A. Nelson-Williams C. Rossier B.C. Lifton R.P. Nat. Genet. 1996; 13: 248-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (722) Google Scholar). In addition, apparent overactivity of this channel, seen in the presence of common mutations of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator, has been linked to the pathogenesis of airway disease in cystic fibrosis (4Boucher R.C. Stutts M.J. Knowles M.R. Cantley L.C. Gatzy J.T. J. Clin. Invest. 1986; 78: 1245-1252Crossref PubMed Scopus (446) Google Scholar). However, little is known about how ENaC activity is regulated under different physiological states. The primary structure of ENaC was elucidated through expression cloning (5Burch L.H. Talbot C.R. Knowles M.R. Canessa C.M. Rossier B.C. Boucher R.C. Am. J. Physiol. 1995; 269: C511-C518Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and revealed that the channel is formed by three homologous subunits, α, β, and γ. When these three subunits are expressed together in Xenopus oocytes, they produce a channel with the typical biophysical and pharmacologic properties of the native channel: low conductance, high Na+/K+ selectivity, and sensitivity to amiloride in the submicromolar range (1Garty H. Palmer L.G. Physiol. Rev. 1997; 77: 359-396Crossref PubMed Scopus (1043) Google Scholar, 5Burch L.H. Talbot C.R. Knowles M.R. Canessa C.M. Rossier B.C. Boucher R.C. Am. J. Physiol. 1995; 269: C511-C518Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Puoti A. May A. Canessa C.M. Horisberger J.-D. Schild L. Rossier B.C. Am. J. Physiol. 1995; 269: C188-C197Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, the open probability of this channel in oocytes is much higher than in most tissues, suggesting that this expression system lacks physiologically important regulation machinery for ENaC (7Alvarez de la Rosa D. Zhang P. Naray-Fejes-Toth A. Fejes-Toth G. Canessa C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 37834-37839Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). Moreover, the expression, activity, stoichiometry, and trafficking of ENaC in various tissues appears to be differentially regulated and complex. Thus, a complete understanding of ENaC trafficking and regulation requires examination of these processes in cells from tissues that express the channel endogenously. We have investigated the trafficking and turnover of individual ENaC subunits in the hormonally responsive Xenopus kidney cell line A6. Interestingly, we find that Xenopus ENaC subunits (xENaCs) at the apical cell surface have different half-lives and that xENaC subunits traffic to the cell surface in a non-coordinate fashion in response to a subset of transport-modulating agents. In particular, our data suggest a model in which cell surface xENaC activity can be regulated by the selective insertion or removal of β-xENaC. A6 cells were maintained in amphibian medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum (BioWhittaker, Walkersville, MD) at 28 °C in 5% CO2. For experiments, cells were seeded at high density on permeable supports (0.4-μm pore, Costar, Cambridge, MA or Millipore, Bedford, MA) and used at least 8 days post-plating. HeLa cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Atlanta Biologicals, Norcross, GA), streptomycin (100 μg/ml), and penicillin (100 units/ml). (9Zuckerman J.B. Chen X. Jacobs J.D. Hu B. Kleyman T.R. Smith P.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 23286-23295Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Expression of xENaC subunits in HeLa cells was performed essentially as described in Weisz et al. (10Weisz O.A. Swift A.M. Machamer C.E. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 1185-1196Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). HeLa cells were plated on 35-mm dishes at approximately 40% confluence. The following day, cells were infected at 37 °C with recombinant vaccinia virus encoding T7 RNA polymerase (vTF7.3) at a multiplicity of infection of 10–20. After adsorption for 30 min, the inoculum was replaced with 0.75 ml of serum-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 3 μg of total DNA and 5 μl of LipofectAMINE (Life Technologies, Inc.). At 3 h post-infection, cells were starved for 15 min in cysteine-free, methionine-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, then labeled for 2 h with 100 μCi/ml [35S]methionine (in vitro labeling mix; PerkinElmer Life Sciences). After rinsing with phosphate-buffered saline, cells were lysed in detergent solution (50 mm Tris, pH 8.0, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.4% deoxycholate, 62.5 mm EDTA, and 1 μg/ml aprotinin). After brief centrifugation (1 min at maximal speed in a microcentrifuge) to remove nuclei, SDS was added to a final concentration of 0.2%. Lysates were immunoprecipitated using the appropriate anti-xENaC antibodies, eluted, divided into two aliquots, and mock-treated or treated with N-glycanase (New England BioLabs, Beverly, MA). Samples were immunoprecipitated using the appropriate anti-xENaC antibodies and electrophoresed on 10% SDS-PAGE gels. Radiolabeled bands were visualized using phosphorimaging with Quantity One software (Personal Molecular Imager FX; Bio-Rad). A6 cells were mock-treated or treated with aldosterone (1 μmfor 18 h or 3 h), ADH (100 milliunits/ml for 30 min), insulin (100 milliunits/ml for 30 min), BFA (5 μg/ml for 3 h) or amiloride (100 μm for 18 h). Transepithelial potential difference and short circuit current (Isc) were measured using a sterile in-hood short-circuiting device as described previously (11Steele R.G. Handler J.S. Preston A.S. Johnson J.P. Am. J. Physiol. 1986; 251: C186-C190Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). A6 cells were starved for 30 min, then radiolabeled for 1 h and chased for 0–4 h. Individual filters were solubilized in detergent solution, and ENaC subunits were immunoprecipitated as described above and analyzed on SDS-PAGE gels. To determine the half-life of ENaC subunits that had reached the apical membrane, A6 cells grown on 6-well filter inserts were chilled and biotinylated on ice with sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin (Pierce). Cells were subsequently returned to 28 °C for various chase periods. At each time point, cells were solubilized, biotinylated subunits were recovered by binding to streptavidin-agarose, and samples were washed and electrophoresed on SDS-PAGE gels. Two filter inserts were combined for each time point. After transfer to nitrocellulose, gels were probed with anti-xENaC antibodies, and the half-life of each subunit tagged at the cell surface was quantitated by measuring the decrease in biotinylated subunit recovered with time. To verify that our antibodies react specifically with xENaC subunits, we expressed α-, β-, and γ-xENaC from cDNA in HeLa cells using recombinant vaccinia virus and immunoprecipitated radiolabeled cells using anti α-, β-, or γ-xENaC antibodies (Fig. 1 A). None of the antibodies recognized proteins from mock-infected HeLa cells. Anti-α-xENaC immunoprecipitated a protein of approximately 65 and 75 kDa from HeLa cells transfected with α-xENaC (Table 1). Anti β-xENaC recognized two bands of molecular masses ∼70 and 97 kDa from cells transfected with β-xENaC, and anti γ-xENaC recognized 2 bands of molecular masses 75 and 95 kDa from cells transfected with γ-xENaC. In the case of α- and γ-xENaC, treatment with N-glycanase resulted in collapse of the more slowly migrating band into the band with faster mobility. Treatment of β-xENaC immunoprecipitates withN-glycanase caused a shift in the migration of the higher molecular mass band; however, this band did not migrate with the lower molecular mass band, suggesting a further post-translational modification of this subunit. The nonglycosylated subunits that we observed in this overexpression system have previously been observed in other heterologous expression systems, and are not membrane associated nor do they represent degradation intermediates (14Valentijn J.A. Fyfe G.K. Canessa C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30344-30351Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). It is likely that these forms are an aberration induced by overexpression. To confirm that endogenous ENaC expressed in A6 cells was glycosylated, we biotinylated the apical membrane of polarized cells, recovered surface proteins using streptavidin-agarose, and treated the samples withN-glycanase. ENaC subunits were then detected by Western blotting (Fig. 1 b). The mobilities of both β- and γ-xENaC shifted to 70 and 75 kDa as expected. However, neitherN-glycanase nor endoglycosidase H treatment affected the mobility of the α-xENaC bands. We suspect that these high molecular mass forms of α-xENaC may be aggregated or modified in such a way that they are resistant to deglycosylation. However, another group has reported that ENaC subunits at the cell surface of CHO cells appear to be deglycosylated (75Prince L.S. Welsh M.J. Biochem. J. 1998; 336: 705-710Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). We used these antibodies to measure the half-life of newly synthesized xENaC subunits as well as xENaC subunits that had reached the apical plasma membrane of polarized A6 cells. Consistent with a previously published study (15May A. Puoti A. Gaeggeler H.-P. Horisberger J.-D. Rossier B.C. J. Am. Soc. Nephrol. 1997; 8: 1813-1822Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) we found that the half-life of newly synthesized ENaC subunits is relatively short in A6 cells, with a half-life of approximately 2 h for each subunit (Fig. 2). In addition, we measured the relative amounts of individual ENaC subunits at the plasma membrane at steady state. Biotinylated proteins were precipitated from 200 μg of cell lysate using streptavidin-agarose, electrophoresed, and Western-blotted using antibodies against the individual xENaC subunits (Fig. 3, right lane). The signal was compared with the amount of each ENaC subunit in 40 μg of cell lysate (Fig. 3, left lane). Based on this and other similar experiments, we estimate that that roughly 20% of each subunit is at the cell surface under steady state conditions. Importantly, this steady state distribution of ENaC subunits is considerably higher than that reported in oocytes (14Valentijn J.A. Fyfe G.K. Canessa C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30344-30351Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar), where less than 1% of the total subunits were detected at the plasma membrane. This observation suggests that there could be significant differences in the regulation of ENaC traffic between this overexpression system and cells that endogenously express the channel.Figure 3Steady state distribution of xENaC subunits in A6 cells. Approximately 20% of the total xENaC in the cells could be biotinylated.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Because a large fraction of newly synthesized ENaC is rapidly degraded and does not reach the cell surface, the short half-life we measured for newly synthesized subunits does not accurately reflect the half-life of ENaC that has reached the cell surface. Therefore, we biotinylated the apical membrane of polarized A6 cells and measured the rate of degradation of individual ENaC subunits over time (Fig. 4). Interestingly, all of the ENaC subunits at the plasma membrane had considerably longer half-lives compared with newly synthesized subunits. Surprisingly, however, we consistently observed that the rate of degradation of cell surface β-xENaC was considerably faster (∼6-h half-life) than that of α- or γ-xENaC, which remained relatively stable over the 24-h time course. The long half-life of α-xENaC that has reached the cell surface has also been independently verified in Dr. Thomas Kleyman's laboratory. 2T. Kleyman, personal communication. The surprising observation that ENaC subunits have different rates of degradation upon reaching the cell surface suggests the possibility that individual subunits might traffic to or from the plasma membrane independently (non-coordinately). ENaC activity has been reported to be up-regulated by various hormone treatments including aldosterone, ADH, and insulin. Stimulation of ENaC channel activity by aldosterone occurs in two phases: an initial, acute phase (within 1–3 h of stimulation), thought to involve activation of silent or inactive channels resident in the apical membrane, and a late phase, (upon overnight stimulation) whose mechanism is unknown. The mechanism of action of these agents in kidney remains unclear but does not appear to involve synthesis of new channel subunits. By contrast, hyperpolarization with the sodium channel inhibitor amiloride appears to decrease ENaC activity as an adaptive response (16Ling B.N. Eaton D.C. Am. J. Physiol. 1989; 256: F1094-F1103PubMed Google Scholar). We therefore tested the effects of these treatments on ENaC activity in A6 cells. As expected, treatment with aldosterone (both short (3 h) and long (18 h) term), ADH (30 min), and insulin (30 min) increased short circuit current in A6 cells (Table II). By contrast, treatment for 3 h with the fungal metabolite BFA, which inhibits delivery of newly synthesized proteins to the plasma membrane, decreased amiloride-sensitive current (Table II). Next, we tested whether the same treatments affected the surface density of xENaC subunits in the apical membrane. To do this, we incubated A6 cells with aldosterone (3 or 18 h), ADH (30 min), insulin (30 min), or BFA (3 h), then biotinylated the apical domains of the cells. The cells were then solubilized, and biotinylated proteins were collected with streptavidin-agarose, electrophoresed, transferred to nitrocellulose, and blotted with anti-xENaC antibodies (Fig. 5). The level of α-xENaC recovered after these treatments was generally unaffected, although a slight (∼10%) but statistically significant decrease in apical α-xENaC was observed upon treatment with ADH. By contrast, the amount of β-xENaC at the apical surface was dramatically elevated in cells treated for 18 h with aldosterone (∼60% increase;p < 0.01) or for 30 min with ADH (∼20% increase;p < 0.01). Treatment with insulin or short term incubation with aldosterone had no effect on the density of β-xENaC at the apical membrane, whereas incubation with BFA reduced apical β-xENaC levels. These striking results were reproducibly observed in multiple experiments, including several experiments in which the same blots were stripped and sequentially probed with individual anti-xENaC antibodies in random order.Table IIChanges in short circuit current in response to various transporting conditionsConditionIse (μA/cm2) mean ± S.D.Control, n = 824.4 ± 1.3Aldosterone 3h, n = 8013.8 ± 3.8Aldosterone 18h, n = 6624.8 ± 10.9ADH 30 min, n= 5910.7 ± 4.5Insulin 30 min, n = 3112.1 ± 2.8BFA 3h, n = 580.8 ± 0.8A6 cells grown on permeable supports were mock-treated with the indicated hormones or drugs and short circuit was measured as described under “Materials and Methods”.
